history.content:
EE126,127 and CS189 are the essentials. Do an internship and save yourself the trouble of DS100, which is a super buggy and beta class that grades as if it isn’t, and is basically a survey of data science that you will pick up quickly through personal projects that you should probably do anyways.

_____________________________

I disagree with ^. Machine learning and data science are not synonyms. Data science uses machine learning as a tool. If you're interested in strengthening your ML theoretical foundation, EE126/7 is a great option. But if you're interested in getting a feel of hands-on, applied and practical experience of the whole data science lifecycle (data collection, ETL, EDA, feature engineering / hyperparameter tuning, prediction/inference), I recommend DS100. It's a great course :) 

^

Definitely agree with second comment, and not first. DS100 is likely overall more valuable to becoming a data scientist than any other class @ Cal. Yes, Machine learning may end up being a part of your education, but who cares if you have no idea how to work with actual data? 

____

First answerer here. OP talks about Data Science/ML in their question, which to me indicates that they are interested in the ML part of data science. They also mention 189. After I took DS100, my person recommendation is that it is largely a waste of time, and several students agree with me — check the FB course advice group, where there is a similar thread. Even if it were well organized, which it is not and continues to be a mess of bugs and imbalance in difficulty and scope, the course content is mostly things you would pick up on the way to becoming a data scientist anyways. I would not recommend it at all for someone who is trying to become one either, since you will be either hopelessly lost or bored. In any case, anybody who has strong work in 126,127, and 189, can learn DS100 content by themselves, but taking DS100 will not prepare you in any way for more difficult projects.

____

Second answerer (sorry for the confusion). Like I said, ML and Data Science are not the same. Even if you're interested in the ML part of data science, chances are you will be using it as an applied manner and not theoretical manner. If applied ML is what you're looking for, you do not have to know the line by line math theory behind ML (although it helps with the intuition). I'm currently interning as a Data Scientist in Microsoft, and although my project is deep learning based, I can confidently tell you I'm using more of what I've learnt in DS100 than any other course so far (including CS189). Taking the course will ONLY help you, and will not hurt you, as an aspiring data scientist.

EE126,127 and CS189 are the essentials. Do an internship and save yourself the trouble of DS100, which is a super buggy and beta class that grades as if it isn’t, and is basically a survey of data science that you will pick up quickly through personal projects that you should probably do anyways.

I'll be taking cs 189 later, I wasn't sure which of these two is a better option for someone interested in ML/data science
history.subject: Data 100 or CS 186 for Data Science/ML
